q1.explanation: The root directory in Linux is / (forward slash), which is the top of the entire filesystem tree

q2.explanation: 755 means owner has rwx (7), group has r-x (5), and others have r-x (5)

q3.explanation: Git workflow is: add (stage changes) → commit (save to repo) → push (upload to remote)

q4.explanation: tail -f follows a file in real-time, essential for watching log files

q5.explanation: Feature branches allow working on features without affecting the stable main branch

q6.explanation: In Linux philosophy, everything (including hardware devices) is represented as a file for uniform interface

q7.explanation: rm -rf / is EXTREMELY DANGEROUS and will delete everything on the system. Never run this command!

q8.explanation: git pull = git fetch (download changes) + git merge (integrate changes)

q9.explanation: Ubuntu uses apt, CentOS uses yum/dnf. Different package managers for different distros.

q10.explanation: Merge conflicts occur when the same lines are modified differently in separate branches

key_points: > creates new file if doesn't exist
Git allows reverting to previous versions
Git shows who made what changes and when
